entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-02
entry.content:
• The Woman Who Needed to Be Upside-Down
    One of the stranger medical stories I’ve heard so far.
  • CIA interrogation probe ends without any charges
    Everything else would have been rather surprising.
  • «Ein oder mehrere Mitgliedstaaten glauben, dass Sie eine Gefahr sind»
    Brave New Fortress Europe (in German).
  • The humans who outrun horses
    Very interesting article on how humans evolved into long-distance runners.
  • 37signals Earns Millions Each Year. Its CEO’s Model? His Cleaning Lady
    Nice interview with Jason Fried of 37signals fame.
  • DNA test jailed innocent man for murder
    If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear. Yeah, right.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-06-24
entry.content:
It was like finding out your husband didn’t just cheat, but had a frequent-flier account with every brothel in North America for the past 10 years.

Matt Taibbi http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/the-scam-wall-street-learned-from-the-mafia-20120620 The Scam Wall Street Learned From the Mafia

  • I Don’t “Get” Art
    More than once I found myself at an exhibition with exactly the same thoughts.
  • I’ve been playing the same game of Civilization II for almost 10 years. This is the result.
    A Redditor describes the in-game worl of a game of Civilization II he’s been playing for 10 years. Also see the new subreddit, the interview with Sid Meier and a player who managed to save the world.
  • Colours in movie posters since 1914
    I love how engineers tackle all sorts of problems.
  • The Kachin borderlands
    China’s political and economic impact on Burma’s border state Kachin.
  • Top US universities put their reputations online
    On the online courses offered by MIT, Harvard and Stanford.
  • The Great German Energy Experiment
    After Fukushima Germany decided to change its energy policies. Was this really a wise decision?
  • The Scam Wall Street Learned From the Mafia
    Another great article by the Rolling Stone, I always like how direct they are.
  • Lebenslang für Norwegen
    The Breivik trial is coming to its end, but the scars in the Norwegian psyche are deep (in German).
  • When My Crazy Father Actually Lost His Mind
    A touching personal account of a family dealing with mental illness.
  • Like a prion, Alzheimer’s protein seeds itself in the brain
    Always good to see some new research on a disease like Alzheimer’s.

entry.title: Information Overload 2011-07-03
entry.content:
• "New Car Engine Sends Shock Waves Through Auto Industry":http://news.discovery.com/autos/new-car-engine-sends-shockwaves-through-auto-industry-110405.html
    Interesting new concept for an energy-efficient engine, with a possible prototype by the end of the year.
  • "Sugar rush":http://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/06/diabetes
    Interesting info graphic on the increase of diabetes around the world. In Austria the last 30 years saw an increase of 30-46% for women and over 60% for men.
  • "What Google+ Learned from Buzz and Wave":http://smarterware.org/8248/what-google-learned-from-buzz-and-wave
    Since Google+ is all the hype this week, I had to include an article on it. At least this one has some actual content.
  • "Pruney fingers grip better":http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110628/full/news.2011.388.html
    The wringly fingers we get when bathing? There actually might be a good reason for that.
  • "Time to Close the Security Theater":http://blogs.forbes.com/artcarden/2011/06/30/time-to-close-the-security-theater/
    This is Forbes quoting Bruce Schneier and calling for abolishing the TSA, while also suggesting "a competitive market for air travel in which the airports, the airways, and the airliners are in private hands". I agree with one of the above two points, can you guess which? ;-)
  • "A Party that smiles to the world, but tightens its grip at home":http://www.information.dk/272094
    Having lived in China, I'm always interested in what's going on in the country. From what I saw on Twitter over the last few month, the document cited in this article may well be real.
  • "Pharmageddon: how America got hooked on killer prescription drugs":http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/09/us-drugs-oxycodone-painkillers-florida
    While the headline is terrible, the article tackles a very real problem, prescription drug abuse in the US.
  • "The Kempner Series - A modified harmonic series":http://hippomath.blogspot.com/2011/07/kempner-series-modified-harmonic-series.html
    Interesting how little it takes to make the harmonic series convergent.
  • "Dasein unter Plastikmüll":http://derstandard.at/1308679612170/Suedspanien-Dasein-unter-Plastikmuell
    An interview about the situation of migrant workers in Almeria. Is this what the European Union wants to stand for? (in German)
  • "Is Sugar Toxic?":http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/17/magazine/mag-17Sugar-t.html?_r=3&pagewanted=all
    Now that people are getting wary of H.F.C.S., some scientists start suspecting that "normal" sugar isn't much better.
